The Kuhnian revolution and the postmodernist turn in the history of science. Physis, 1993, 30: 476-504. 42 Clark, William. Narratology and the his- tory of science. Stud. Hist. Phil. Sci., 1995, 26: 1-71. 'This essay is about the narrative structure of Charles Gillispie's The Edge of Objectivity (1960), Steven Shapin's and Simon Schaffer's Leviathan and the Air-Pump (1985), Martin Rudwick's The Great Devonian Controversy (1985), and Donna Haraway's Primate Visions (1989). I intend to read these works in the spirit of a literary critic, whom I'll pretend does something other than an historical or philosophical critic. This essay is not a review of those four books, and you need not have read them in order to read on. My goal is to help further establish literary criticism as an aspect of science studies, and also to subvert 'whig history' as a historiographic concept." 43 Dear, Peter. Cultural history of science: An overview with reflections. Sci. Technol. Hum. Val., 1995, 20: 150-170. 44 Grmek, Mirko D. Quelques mythes methodologiques en histoire des sciences. Pp. 205-223 in Kostas Gavroglu (et al., eds.) Physics, philosophy, and the scientific community. Dordrecht: Kluwer Academic, 1995. 46 Iliffe, Rob. Theory, experiment and society in French and Anglo-Saxon history of science. Eur. Rev. Hist., 1995, 2: 65-77. Examines the analysis of the role of scientific experiment by three French scholars: Bachelard, Koyrd, and Latour. Argues "that while Anglo-Saxons were slow to embrace French anti-empiricism, French historians of science have been unwilling to consider that the content of science might itself be linked to various social and cultural con- texts that surround its production." 47 Kikuchi, Toshiyoshi. (Philosophy of history and culture, 13.) xi + 161 pp., bibl., index. Leiden: Brill, 1994. 67 Aronson, Jerrold L.; Harre, Rom; Way, Eileen Cornell. Paris: Presses de l'?cole Normale Superieure, 1994. 72 Brenner, Anastasios. La logique de l'6volution scientifique. Sci. Tech. Persp., 1995, 31: 87-92. 73 Brewer, William F.; Chinn, Clark A. Sci- entists' responses to anomalous data: Evidence from psychology, history, and philosophy of science. PSA, 1994(1): 304-313. 'The purpose of this paper is to provide a systematic account of the role of anomaly in theory change in sci- ence. We adopt a naturalist approach to the philosophy of science and support our proposal with evidence from the history of science and from the psychology of science." 74 Brush, Stephen G. Are the soft sciences too hard? Contention, 1995, 4(2): 3-12. "My conclusion is not that social scientists, and students of revolution in particular, should give up the search for testable predictions; rather, it is that they may have been led by writings on scientific method to adopt unrealistic standards of theory-evaluation, and thus to be too critical of theories." Followed (pp. 13-16) by a commentary by Theodore M. Porter, "Prediction and method in science." 75 Callebaut, Werner. The normative issue in naturalistic philosophy of science. Theoria, 1995, 22: 101-116. 76 The Cambridge companion to Foucault. Edited by Gary Gutting. xii + 360 pp., notes, bibl., index. Cambridge: Cambridge Univ. Press, 1994. Dialectical ma- terialism and modem science. vi + 245 pp., notes, index. New York: International Publish- ers, 1995. 78 Castelao-Lawless, Teresa. Phenomenotech- nique in historical perspective: Its origins and implications for philosophy of science. Phil. Sci., 1995, 62: 44-59. 'This article provides an overview of the historical and philosophical context from which originated G. Bachelard's concept of 'phenomenotechnique'. It analyzes why phe- nomenotechnique is crucial for science studies. By incor- porating the concept of phenomenotechnique into Hacking's and Galison's models of science, I argue that we can avoid the radicalism of both while also preventing the analysis of scientific practices from collapsing into the in- terpretive frames mandated by social constructivists." A visible hand in the marketplace of ideas: Precision measurement as arbitrage. Sci. Context, 1994, 7: 563- 589. "While there has been much attention given to experiment in modem science studies, there has been astoundingly little concern spared over the practice of quantitative measurement. Thus myths about the unreasonable ef- fectiveness of mathematics in science still abound. This paper presents: (a) an explicit mathematical model of the stabilization of quantitative constants in a mathematical science to rival older Bayesian and classical accounts; (b) a framework for writing a history of practices with regard to treatment of quantitative measurement error; (c) resources for the comparative sociology of differing disci- plines in this regard; and (d) a prolegomena to a critique of orthodox economics and accounting theories." 196 Murphy, Raymond. Epige- netic inheritance and evolution: The Lamarck- ian dimension. xiii + 346 pp., notes, glossary, bibl., index. Oxford: Oxford Univ. Press, 1995. 467 Keller, Evelyn Fox. The body of a new machine: Situating the organism between tele- graphs and computers. Perspect. Sci., 1994, 2: 302-323. "Genes and messages have a long association in biology, dating back at least to Weismann. But, through most of this history, even with the dramatic concreteness that molecular biology lent to this association, the image dom- inating most thinking about messages was drawn from the 19th-century technology of the telegraph. In the mid-20th century, a new technology, the computer, arrived to dis- place the telegraph. With that displacement, the meanings of many terms-of 'message,' 'information,' 'organization,' indeed, 'organism'-have, over the past few decades, all been transformed. In this article, I explore the computer's impact on biological representation of the organism in two disciplines: molecular biology and developmental biology." 468 Keller, Evelyn Fox. 'The account to follow will show (thereby giving empir- ical support to some studies) that Social Darwinism was less prevalent in those contexts where it was claimed by historians to be strongest. More importantly it will also show that the transfer of the metaphor back from science into public and political discourse entails a loss of its original meaning, or more precise yet, the loss of any meaning relation. It will show further, that the meaning of the metaphor changes as its conceptual environment changes." 25b. Psychology 494 Becklen, Robert C. Press, 1994. 706 Miller, Peter; O'Leary, Ted. The factory as laboratory. Sci Context, 1994, 7: 469- 496. "This paper argues that science and technology studies need to adopt a much wider view of what counts as a laboratory. The factory, it is suggested, is as much a site of invention and intervention as the laboratory. As a site for the government of economic life, the factory is a laboratory par excellence. One particular factory is studied-the Decatur, Illinois, plant of Caterpillar Inc.-as it is rethought and remade in accordance with ideals of cellular manufacturing, Just-in-Time systems, customer- driven manufacturing, and competitor benchmarking." 707 Mills, Allan A. Con- text, 1994, 7: 515-537. "While recognizing that public sector research has long been managed by a wide variety of practices and tech- niques, this paper concentrates on the increasingly im- portant role that patents are playing in the management and regulation of public sector research. It argues that as a specific form of technology, patents play a significant and growing role in facilitating the management of the scientific object and can also be seen as a particular in- stance of governmentality. More specifically, it argues that patents have had an important impact on the culture and political economy of science." 721 Simpson, Lorenzo C. "I shall first consider the larger conceptual context of Aristotle's physics as well as several important points in Physics IV, then turn to the vexatious argument of Physics IV, 8, to consider what 'faster' and 'greater speed' mean and how to construe this argument. I shall conclude that in Aristotle 'faster' does not mean 'greater speed.' Indeed, as I shall suggest, substituting 'greater speed' for 'faster' redefines first this argument and then physics as a science." 863 Lang, Helen S. The exact sciences (pure mathematics, optics, astronomy, music, theoretical mechan- ics, experimental physical sciences) 1099 Aiken, Jane Andrews. Truth in images: From the technical drawings of Ibn al-Razzaz al-Jazari, Campanus of Novara, and Giovanni de'Dondi to the perspective projection of Leon Battista Alberti. Viator, 1994, 25: 325-359. 'The drawings of planetary clocks, dials, and astrolabes by the fourteenth-century philosopher/astronomer Giovanni de'Dondi, as well as those by the thirteenth-century Italian mathematician Campanus of Novara and the Arab engineer Ibn al-Razzaz al-Jazari, signaled a new response to an ever more complex technology. Taken together, they reflect a growing, cumulative, commitment among erudite craftsmen to the twin standards of mathematical rigor and illusionistic credibility, the very hallmarks of Alberti's more famous method of projections." State, cosmos, and body in the last three centuries B.C. Harvard J. Asia. Stud., 1995, 55: 5-37. 'This essay examines the explicit connections between the cosmos, the body, and the state in China up to the end of the first century B.C. It asks what structure underlies these connections, and concludes that the word 'connections' may be misleading. In China ideas of Nature, state, and the body were so interdependent that they are best considered a single complex." 35.2b. Taal- Letterk., 1995, 111: 55-64. "At the end of the 16th century the scientist Simon Stevin and the lexicographer Cornelis Kiliaan were most deserving in their efforts for the study of Dutch vocabulary. Up to now one thought, without a serious investigation, that the scientific works of Stevin had not been used by Kiliaan as sources for his dictionary. However, an exhaustive examination of words which were recorded by Stevin for the first time, demonstrates that Kiliaan has actually taken over several words from Stevin." Zabarella e la scienza moderna: Connessioni e divergenze. Physis, 1994, 31: 371-391. "From a careful examination of the Zabarellian concep- tion of science, in its instrumentalistic, metaphysical and ontological implications, the author goes on to study the kinetic theories proposed in De motu gravium et levium, examining their connections with the medieval tradition and their innovative aspects. After pointing out the ab- sence of any mention of the theory of regressus in De rebus naturalibus, possible relations between Zabarella's and Galileo's De motu are examined, with the purpose of emphasizing how problematical is the link between the Aristotelianism of the Paduan professor and modem phys- ical science, elaborated by the Pisan scientist." "Probatum est per me": The Heidelberg electors as practitioners and patrons of the medical and magical arts. Cauda Pavonis, 1995, 14(1): 12-18. 'This study focuses on the types of medical manuscripts obtained for the Bibliotheca Palatina and examines the contributions and interests of three generations of elec- tors: Philipp der Aufrichtige (Philip the Upright, d. 1508), Ludwig V (d. 1544), and Otto Heinrich (d. 1559). Their initiatives reflected prevailing contemporary attitudes to- ward the medical-and what might be considered today as pseudo-medical-sciences and shaped the tradition of med- ical manuscript collecting and copying in Heidelberg in the sixteenth century. In addition, with electoral impetus and support Heidelberg became a locus for the pursuit of alchemical remedies and experiments by mid-century." 1685 Toellner, Richard. Der Korper des Men- schen in der philosophischen und theologis- chen Anthropologie des spaiten Mittelalters und der beginnenden Neuzeit. Pp. 131-146 in Klaus Schreiner, Norbert Schnitzler (eds.) Plato's hermetic Book of the cow. Pp. 133-145 in Pietro Prini (ed.) II Neoplatonismo nel Rinascimento. Roma: Istituto della Enciclopedia Italiana, 1993. "Near the beginning of his Disputationes adversus as- trologiam divinatricem Pico della Mirandola mentions 'the books of Plato concerning the Cow (which) the magi cause to circulate [. .] filled with execrable dreams and figments'. This paper presents an attempt to define the origins-in part Neoplatonic-of the execrable dreams con- tained in the Book of the Cow, to explain how its magic works in tandem with its gemellus, the celestial magic of the Picatrix generally so much more familiar to histori- ans of Renaissance Neoplatonism, and finally to examine what little evidence there is for the popularity of this text during the Renaissance." 1728 Preda, Alessandra. Leibniz: De- terminist, theist, idealist. xi + 433 pp., notes, bibl., index. New York: Oxford Univ. Press, 1994. 1735 Adamson, Donald. Blaise Pascal: Math- ematician, physicist and thinker about God. xii + 297 pp., notes, bibl., index. New York: St. Martin's Press, 1995. 1736 Ariew, Roger. Damned if you do: Carte- sians and censorship, 1663-1706. Perspect. Sci., 1994, 2: 255-274. "I consider two events in late 17th-century philosophy: (i) the condemnation of Cartesianism by the church, the throne, and the university and (ii) the noncondemnation of Gassendism by the same powers. What is striking about the two events is that both Cartesians and Gassendists accepted the same proposition deemed heretical. Thus, what was sufficient to condemn Cartesianism was not sufficient to condemn Gassendism. As a result, I suggest that to understand what is involved in condemnation one has to pay close attention to the intellectual and/or social context and to rhetorical strategy, not just to the propositions condemned. In this case, what is at stake are some of the central propositions of corpuscularianism and the mechanical philosophy." 1737 Ariew, Roger; Grene, Marjorie. Ideas, in and before Descartes. J. Hist. Ideas, 1995, 56: 87-106. 1738 Armogathe, Jean-Robert. Stmantese de ratio/raison dans le corpus cart6sien. Pp. 403- 413 in M. Fattori, M.L. Bianchi (eds.) Ra- tio: VII Colloquio Internazionale. Tradition and innovation in early modem natural philosophy: Jean Bodin and Jean-Cecile Frey. Perspect. Sci., 1994, 2: 428-454. "Traditional natural philosophy with its bookish methods and basic indebtedness to Aristotle harbored innovations of many different kinds in the late Renaissance. I compare the modes of innovation and of adherence to tradition in the Universae naturae theatrum (1596) of Jean Bodin, who worked outside the university although his work was cited by German professors, and in the university teaching of Jean-Cecile Frey (active in Paris 1618-31). I argue that authorial self-presentation and ideas about the proper relation of philosophy and religion played crucial roles in making innovations palatable or not in different university contexts." Edmond Halley's use of historical evidence in the advancement of science. Notes Rec. Roy. Soc. Lond., 1994, 48: 167-191. "Like the antiquarians and literary scholars of his age, Halley displayed a fascination with and an informed crit- ical awareness of human history, as it was understood in the late 17th century. This awareness, moreover, was not just concerned with astronomical topics, but suffused his general thought-process to make him see the overall inves- tigation of nature as rooted within a cultural context that can only be called historical." 99</page><page sequence="100">37.1a. From the abstract. 1776 Eamon, William. Science as a hunt. Physis, 1994, 31: 393-432. "The metaphor of science as a hunt was widely used to define scientific activity in the early modem period. In contrast to medieval natural philosophers, who tended to regard science as an attempt to demonstrate the known, early modem intellectuals thought of science as a search for new and unknown facts, and of causes concealed beneath nature's outer appearances. The metaphor of science as a hunt, which was shaped largely by courtly discourse and by the conditions of princely patronage, captured this new conception of science and the novel epistemology it implied." 1777 Ehrman, James F. Translation, world view, and time: Rewriting organic science in translation. Diss. Abstr. Int., 1994, 55: 1572- A. Dissertation at Univ. of Texas at Austin, 1994. Supervisor: Andrd Lefevere. Univ. Microfilms order no. 94-28509. 173 pp. A comparative analysis of Roger Bacon's Specu- lum alchimiae with a 1692 translation by William Salmon, and Paracelsus's Liber de nymphis, sylphis, pygmaeis et salamandris et de caeteris spiritis with a 1964 transla- tion by Manly Hall, shows that "information presupposed by the original is significantly as well as predictably al- tered in translation to fit the constraints of a new way of thinking." 1778 Emerton, Norma E. "In every drop of dew": Imagination and the rhetoric of assent in En- glish natural religion. Rhetorica, 1994, 12: 293-325. "Seventeenth-century 'natural religion' in England in- cluded the work of many theologians and scientists who comprised a close-knit discourse community shaped by a common theology and many similarities in intellectual outlook. They developed a complex rhetoric compounded of probabilistic reasoning and a wide range of figurative conventions for the argument from design. These writ- ings offer a rich intertext of discursive practices which are more classically rooted, more intuitive and imagina- tive in appeal, and simultaneously more probabilistic and less demonstrative in reasoning, than has generally been assumed. This essay focuses on the imaginative, figurative dimensions of this work, identifying its primary classical sources and its sanctions in the rhetorical theory of the time." Sci., 1995, 52: 403-410. "In the trial of Galileo there is a small but significant discrepancy between the text of his condemnation by the Holy Office and the text of his recantation, which has been generally overlooked or ignored. The offence that he was required to recant was more serious than the one of which he had been found guilty. The most plausible explanation seems to be that the two texts were drawn up independently of each other by the Inquisitors and the Pope respectively, and that the latter wished to deal more harshly with Galileo than the former. There is some independent evidence for this supposition." 1854 Rutherford, Donald. Leibniz and the rational order of nature. xiii + 301 pp., notes, bibl., index. Cambridge: Cambridge Univ. "What I propose to do in this paper is to consider whether the milieu of English atomism was really dormant until the impact of Gassendi, and whether Gassendi is in fact the most important factor in trying to understand the atomistic theories of the 'Newcastle' or 'Cavendish Circle'. To do this I propose to look at a narrowly delineated field of atomic theory, that of the nature and properties of fire- atoms, or atomistic explanations of heat and flame. I will focus my initial attention on Walter Warner, whose role as a client of the Earl of Northumberland, and a petitioner for the patronage of Charles Cavendish, forms a tenuous link between these two groupings." 1931 Coles, B.R. Culture and society in the Stuart Restoration: Literature, drama, history. Cambridge: Cambridge Univ. Press, 1995. 'This paper links one aspect of the genealogy of Newton's Principia to the processes of self-fashioning which its author adopted. I examine how Newton prepared the Principia for publication during the mid-1680s in the light of his belief that the Ancients had once possessed the true religion and philosophy, and then lost it because of idolatrous tendencies. I demonstrate how he controlled accounts of the meaning of the Principia by selectively allowing access to himself and to his private notes." 1967 Johann Adam Schall von Bell SJ, 1592- 1666: Ein Kolner Astronom am Chinesischen Hof. Context, 1995, 8: 133-157. 2109 Hickey, Daniel. Sixteenth century hos- pital reform: Henri IV and the Chamber of Christian Charity. Renaiss. Reform., 1993, 17(4): 5-15. "Summary: Created in 1606, the Chamber of Christian Charity was intended to fund pensions for former army officers and amputated soldiers by reviewing the operations and expropriating surplus revenues from local charitable foundations-abbeys, monasteries, hospices and local hospi- tals. This article explores the reasons behind Henri IV's initiative and the new methods used-royal commissioners and a centralized approach-to try to resolve what was seen as a traditional problem of corruption and redundancy in French poor relief structures. It will analyse the diffi- culties encountered by the Chamber and the legal obstacles to the whole effort to intervene in local municipal and ecclesiastical institutions to show that the experiment never produced the anticipated results and was abandoned shortly after the king's assassination in 1610." 2110 Kinzelbach, Annemarie. Kant's theory of imagination: Bridging gaps in judgement and experience. (Oxford philosophical mono- graphs.) viii + 205 pp., notes, index. Oxford: Clarendon Press, 1994. 2463 Goutte, Pierre-Henri. Les lph6mirides du citoyen, instrument pdriodique au service de l'ordre naturel (1765-1772). Dix-huit. Siecle, 1994, 26: 139-161. "A study of the 1OphgmWrides du citoyen reveals a remark- able convergence between a scientific project (to 'discover' evidence of the natural order) and the medium used to achieve it. The Physiocrats studied, on the one hand, great empires to prove that order is unchanging and, on the other, the identity of individual and national interest to show its universal character. By writing in a periodi- cal they chose a means of information that was in itself demonstrative. They were forced to reply periodically to any future event likely to bring into question, even partially, the existence of an eternal order; they received articles, book reviews, official documents and chronicles which supported their ideas and popularised them in order to show the readers their true interest which, according to the editors, should lead them to follow the principles of the universal order." From the English abstract. 2464 Gray, Richard. Die Geburt des Genies aus dem Geiste der Aufldnrung: Semiotik und Aufldiirungsideologie in der Physiognomik Johann Kaspar Lavaters. Founding of the Lawrence Scientific School at Harvard Uni- versity, 1846-1847: A study in writing and history. Archivaria, 1994, 38: 119-130. "The goal of the paper is to explore the nature of written communication in a particular historical context, to show how writing related to events in a narrowly defined time period, but, in doing so, to suggest a perspective that should have wider historiographic interest." 2636 Elliott, Clark A. Science at Harvard University, 1846-47: A case study of the character and functions of written documents. Amer. Arch., 1994, 57: 448-460. "This paper explores surviving documentation and what it reveals about the underlying social structure and relations in a historic time and place. The mid-nineteenth century is chosen as a period prior to modem bureaucracies so that documents are not found in defining filing systems. Some six hundred documents are studied individually and characterized collectively. They are examined not to tell a story, however, but for evidence of their creation and maintenance and of their physical types, functional char- acteristics, and relations between authors and recipients." "Ernst Mach and Max Planck debated 'the ends of sci- ence' in the first decade of this century, a time marked by both science's increasing involvement in the means of social reproduction and growing concern that science pur- sued for its own sake was exhibiting diminishing marginal returns on investment. In analyzing Planck's victory, I conclude that its legacy has been an ever-widening gap between the 'content' and 'function' of scientific knowl- edge in society, as measured by increasing numbers of jobs that are devoted to mediating the production and distribution of knowledge." 2643 Goethe, Johann Wolfgang von. "In 1805, Jean Potocki (1761-1805) took part in the Rus- sian mission to China as leader of the scientific delegation. The mission failed, owing to disagreement on protocol, and did not go further than Ourga in Mongolia, but the scientists carried out active investigations all over Siberia and made varied and interesting discoveries, including that of the famous mammoth. As, on their return, there was no sign of any recompense, Potocki drew up a report addressed to the Minister Rumjancev, and wrote to him several times in December 1807, which resulted in three scientists being granted pensions. A few weeks later Po- tocki gave up politics. The ten documents published here 149</page><page sequence="150">38b. Microfilms order no. 95-01555. 361 pp. "This work explores the emerging debate over the scientific study of mankind's moral and social con- stitution through an analysis of a cohort of Cambridge undergraduates. This group, termed the "Trinity Coalition", consisted of the scientific polymath William Whewell, historian Connop Thirlwall, theologian Hugh James Rose, political economist Richard Jones, and philologist Julius Hare. Often working in concert, this group struggled with the philosophical foundations of science, morality, and re- ligion in an attempt to develop a new conceptual system consistent with developments in the social, political, and scientific worlds." 2694 Victorian periodicals and Victorian so- ciety. Mathematics (pure and applied mathe- matics, mathematical logic, and statistics) 2699 Alarc6n, Jesus; Rigo, Mirela; Waldegg, Guillermina. La ciencia analitica en la primera mitad del siglo XIX: El teorema del valor intermedio. Mathesis, 1994, 10: 93- 113. 2700 Alborn, Timothy L. A calculating pro- fession: Victorian actuaries among the statisti- cians. Sci. Context, 1994, 7: 433-468. "The case of Victorian actuaries, who worked hard to maintain unique intellectual claims in the competitive life insurance industry while maintaining strong social connections and overlaps in knowledge with organized science, challenges the way both historians of science and sociologists of professions view contending knowledge claims. By observing what motivated actuaries to forge an alliance with men of science in the 1820s, then tracing their gradual recognition of a need to distance themselves from certain of the 'scientific' values that had earlier informed their collective identity, it is possible to make sense of connections as well as disconnections between science and other forms of knowledge. A history of quantification from the actuaries' perspective, in other words, allows us to view science both as and in context." 2701 Alexander, Daniel S. Gaston Darboux and the history of complex dynamics. Hist. Math., 1995, 22: 179-185. "Gaston Darboux's calls in the mid-1870s for a more rigorous approach to analysis were largely ignored by the French mathematical community for quite some time. Gabriel Koenigs's 1884-1885 papers on the iteration of complex functions mark perhaps the earliest instance where Darboux directly influenced a French mathematician to develop a rigorous approach to his subject." Mathesis, 1994, 10: 1-24. "The present article presents and discusses the arguments for and against the well-known historical thesis, according to which Eudoxus' theory of proportions fully antici- pated modem theories of the irrational numbers, such as Dedekind's or Weierstrass'. Special stress is laid upon Dedekind's theory of cuts, and upon Dedekind's own in- terpretation of the putative connection between his theory and Eudoxus'. This interpretation throws new light upon interesting aspects of the historiographical dispute con- cerning Eudoxus and Dedekind, and of nineteenth century mathematics as well." Quart., 1995, 94: 417-465. "Hamilton's discovery of quaternions is not just well- documented, it is also much written about. . . . What differentiates my account from others is my desire to show that Hamilton's work can be grasped within the more general understanding of agency and practice that I call the mangle. Together with the notions of free and forced moves and disciplinary agency, that of the open-endedness of modeling is especially important here, and in what follows I seek to locate the free moves in Hamilton's eventual route to quaternions by setting that trajectory in relation to his earlier attempts to construct systems of 'triplets"'. "The law of definite proportions and the law of multiple proportions are two of the important laws of chemistry associated with the development of the atomic theory in the early 19th century. Siegel (eds.) No truth except in the de- tails: Essays in honor of Martin J. Klein. Dordrecht: Kluwer, 1995. "The emergence of energetics was largely, if not entirely, a German phenomenon. Its main proponents were Georg Helm, a Dresden mathematician and physicist, and Wilhelm Ostwald, the professor of physical chemistry at Leipzig. Both thought that the world view of modem science was moving toward a comprehensive theory of energy. But, as previously noted, they disagreed about the general form that theory would take: Helm believed that it would be a phenomenalist theory, while Ostwald was convinced that it would be realist in character. Each thought, nevertheless, that the thermodynamic writings of Gibbs supported his position." 2804 Dias, Penha Maria Cardoso; Pinto, Simone Pinheiro; Cassiano, Deisemar Hol- landa. Univ., 1994, 13: 193-249. 2837 Jackson, Myles W. A spectrum of belief: Goethe's "republic" versus Newtonian "despo- tism". Soc. Stud. Sci., 1994, 24: 673-701.. "This paper offers a contextualized study of Goethe's Zur Farbenlehre. Goethe's work on colour theory did not merely depict his disdain for the Newtonian doctrine of light and colours: it illustrated his opposition to two ex- treme forms of politics apparent during the first decade of the 19th century-unenlightened despotism and anar- chy. Goethe's prismatic games offered a more accessible epistemology to a wider audience. Hence, he linked what he considered to be the closed circles of interpretation of Newtonianism to Catholicism and the Illuminati. He wished to establish a 'republic of colour theory', in order to subvert the hegemonic control which the Newtonians had established in optics. By using both the prismatic games and the history which Goethe himself provided in Zur Farbenlehre, this paper offers an account of how political narratives shape the meaning of experiment." Fol- lowed by a commentary by Dusan Bjelic and Michael Lynch (pp. 703-724). 2838 James, Frank A.J.L. Science as a cultural ornament: Bunsen, Kirchhoff and Helmholtz in mid-19th-century Baden. Ambix, 1995, 42: 1-9. "It is now widely accepted that in pre-1871 Germany there was keen competition between the Kingdoms, Grand Duchies and Electorates to establish their own separate identities within Germany. By attracting eminent scholars, not only those working in the sciences, to their univer- sities, individual states gained the advantage of being associated with important and distinctive scholarly activity. In this paper I shall suggest not only that this helps ex- plain why particular scientific appointments were made in some states and especially in the Grand Duchy of Baden, but were also essential to the creation of a cultural image of science in the German states." 2839 The John Herschel bicentennial sym- posium held in Herschel School, Clermont 6 March 1992. Trans. Roy. Soc. South Africa, 1994, 49: 147-153. On his contributions to astronomy. 2906 Warwick, Andrew. The laboratory of theory, or what's exact about the exact sciences? Pp. 311-351 in M. Norton Wise (ed.) The values of precision. Princeton, N.J.: Princeton Univ. Press, 1995. "The historical discussion is focused primarily on Britain in the second half of the 19th century, the period when both mathematical physics and precision measurement became professional activities. I shall suggest that pre- cision measurement in the physical laboratory developed coextensively with new techniques of calculation in mathe- matical physics, and that it was the development of these techniques that kept the interface between theory and ex- periment manageable. I shall also argue that the new technologies of calculation employed in physics, especially the mathematical table and the mechanical calculator, were not developed primarily for scientific use, but for much wider commercial and bureaucratic purposes." 2907 Watson, Katherine D. The Vic- torian "geological illustrations" of Crystal Palace Park. Proc. Geol. Assoc., 1993, 104: 181-194. "Crystal Palace Park in southeast London was the site of the first geological 'theme park'. Constructed in 1853-54, this park exhibited complex geological relationships and full-sized reconstructions of extinct vertebrates. Today, this first attempt at mass geological education away from the textbook or museum is neglected, its lessons largely forgotten. This paper attempts to redress this by reviving interest in the scheme as a whole, and by documenting what remains today." 2928 Edney, Matthew H. "One of Hermann Helmholtz's primary contributions to physiological optics was the experimental elaboration of the three-receptor hypothesis for explaining color vision, a theory first proposed by Thomas Young. Early in his career, however, Helmholtz had publicly rejected the Young hypothesis. My concern in this paper is with the role of experiment and instrumentation in Helmholtz's reversal of position on this issue and more specifically with the positive contribution made by a variety of new media technologies, particularly electric, photographic, and telegraphic inscription devices." 3049 Levi, Peter. "I argue that the study of the 'history of science and religion' could benefit from taking with much greater seri- ousness issues of space, place and geography. Something of the character of the historical geography of the en- counter between science and religion is illustrated first, by an elucidation of the ways in which the geographies of science and religion may be inter-connected, and then by a case study of how 19th century Calvinists in two differ- ent arenas-Belfast and Princeton-responded to Darwinian 168</page><page sequence="169">38e. Nineteenth Century: Biological Sciences evolution. Local regional factors are shown to have been crucially significant in conditioning how religious conser- vatives in different places responded differently to the new biology." "It is my contention that [Darwin] believed that increased divergence leads, not to a decrease in competition, but to an increase in specialization, and that specialization is a competitive advantage in the struggle for existence. Washington: Smithsonian Institution Press, 1994. Originally published in 1981 with the title Savages and scientists. Includes a new foreword by the author. 3158 Israel, Giorgio. The two paths of the mathematization of the social and economic sciences. Physis, 1993, 30: 27-78. "The aim of this paper is to show that two ways were open for the mathematization of social and economic sciences at the end of the 18th century. The first way was to follow the tradition of the arithmdtique politique which was conveyed by Condorcet in the programme of the mathematique sociale: in this approach the calculus of probability had a central role. The other way was to imitate more strictly the analytical-deterministic approach and the mathematical methods of mathematical physics and mechanics. We emphasize here the strong paradigmatic aspects which led to the final success of the second ap- proach and we provide the historical elements explaining this development. We describe also the decline of the tradition of the arithmstique politique and the causes of this decline. Special attention is devoted to the work of the last arithmdticien politicien, E.-E. Duvillard de Durand. The Appendix provides a detailed biography of Duvillard and other unpublished materials." 3159 Jann, Rosemary. Darwin and the anthro- pologists: Sexual selection and its discontents. Victorian Stud., 1994, 37: 287-306. 3160 Jasper, Michael B. From the first edition (1771) to the ninth (1885). 175</page><page sequence="176">38f Nineteenth Century: Social Sciences 3185 Pennock, Robert T. Moral Darwinism: Ethical evidence for the descent of man. Biol. Phil., 1995, 10: 287-307. "Could an ethical theory ever play a substantial evidential role in a scientific argument for an empirical hypothesis? In The descent of man, Darwin includes an extended discussion of the nature of human morality, and the ethical theory which he sketches is not simply developed as an interesting ramification of his theory of evolution, but is used as a key part of his evidence for human descent from animal ancestors. Darwin must rebut the argument that, because of our moral nature, humans are essentially different in kind from other animals and so had to have had a different origin." From the abstract. 3186 Phillips, Dana. Nineteenth-century racial thought and Whitman's 'Democratic ethnology of the future". Nineteenth-Cent. Lit., 1994, 49: 289-320. 3187 Porter, Theodore M. The second Indus- trial Revolution and the staples frontier in Canada: Rethinking knowledge and history. Sci. Canadensis, 1994, 18: 22-37. "In the late 19th century and the early 20th century the exploitation of Canada's softwood forests was transformed by the new technologies of the second Industrial Revo- lution. This can be understood in terms of Innis's staple thesis as the exploitation of natural resources on a mar- gin for and using the technology of a more advanced Euro-American centre. The sociology of knowledge also provides a framework for analysis as old and new bodies of technical knowledge were possessed by and altered the relationships among different social groups. Changes were experienced both in the woods (pulpwood logging) and in the mills (pulp and paper making) in ways which were broadly similar but different in timing and other significant respects." Measuring scientific activity in Canada and Australia before 1915: Exploring some possibilities. Sci. Canadensis, 1994, 17: 27-52. 3529 Kargon, Robert; Leslie, Stuart. Imag- ined geographies: Princeton, Stanford, and the boundaries of useful knowledge in postwar America. Minerva, 1994, 32: 121-143. "The respective paths of Princeton and Stanford Univer- sities to distinction in science were profoundly affected by their respective conceptions of their relations to the region or territory in which they worked. Although both universities had national ambitions for their scientific and engineering programmes, they had different notions of what national eminence meant and how it could be accom- plished. Princeton saw its setting as extending far beyond New Jersey; it saw itself as linked with the national lab- oratories and with Washington, DC itself. Stanford sought to connect itself with business firms and government lab- oratories within its own region. These strikingly different conceptions of their proper territorial setting help to ex- plain why, despite the shared situation of the Cold War, Princeton and Stanford responded as differently as they did to the opportunities available to them." 3530 Kesselring, Thomas. (Berliner Studienreihe zur Mathematik, 5.) 250 pp., illus., notes. Berlin: Heldermann, 1994. 3635 Weintraub, E. Roy; Mirowski, Philip. The pure and the applied: Bourbakism comes to mathematical economics. Sci. Context, 1994, 7: 245-272. "In the minds of many, the Bourbakist trend in mathemat- ics was characterized by pursuit of rigor to the detriment of concern for applications or didactic concessions to the nonmathematician, which would seem to render the concept of a Bourbakist incursion into a field of ap- plied mathematics an oxymoron. We argue that such a conjuncture did in fact happen in postwar mathematical economics, and describe the career of Gerard Debreu to illustrate how it happened. Using the work of Leo Corry on the fate of the Bourbakist program in mathematics, we demonstrate that many of the same problems of the search for a formal structure with which to ground mathematical practice also happened in the case of Debreu. We view this case study as an alternative exemplar to conventional discussions concerning the 'unreasonable effectiveness' of mathematics in science." 3636 Weiss, Bernhard. On Russell's argu- ments for restricting modes of specification and domains of quantification. Hist. Phil. Logic, 1994, 15: 173-188. 3637 Weiss, George H. Physical sciences (astronomy, physics, chemistry) 3642 Aaserud, Finn. Sputnik and the "Prince- ton three": The national security laboratory that was not to be. Hist. Stud. Phys. Biol. Sci., 1995, 25: 185-239. "In the wake of Sputnik two physicists and one economist [John Archibald Wheeler, Eugene Wigner, and Oskar Morgenstem] at Princeton University sought to build a laboratory for basic research serving the military. Although the laboratory as proposed was never established, the rise and fall of their proposal illuminates the relationship between academic science and national defense during the Cold War." 3643 Achinstein, Peter. How to defend a theory without testing it: Niels Bohr and the "logic of pursuit". Pp. 90-120 in Peter A. French (et al., eds.) Midwest studies in philos- ophy, vol. XVIII: Philosophy of science. Notre Dame: Univ. of Notre Dame Press, 1993. 3644 Achinstein, Peter. Jean Perrin and molecular reality. Perspect. Sci., 1994, 2: 396-427. "Jean Perrin's argument for the existence of molecules from his 1908 experimental determination of Avogadro's number raises two questions considered in this article. One is historical: Why as late as 1908 should Perrin have thought it necessary to argue that molecules exist? The other, which takes up the bulk of this article, is philo- sophical: In view of the fact that his argument appears to assume the existence of molecules as a premise, how, if at all, can a charge of circularity be avoided?" The hybridisation of scientific roles and ideas in the context of centres and peripheries. Minerva, 1994, 32: 297-308. A case study of the work of Carothers and Flory on polymer chemistry at Du Pont. "Carothers's polymerisation theory, and Flory's enunciation of equal reactivities, were hybrids of ideas, extensions by analogy of the principles and methods of rigorous scientific disciplines into a new field, still in a state of conceptual unclarity. Their hybrid- ideas were radical innovations which contributed towards establishing polymer chemistry as a separate chemical discipline. Joseph Ben-David's theory of hybridisation can cast new light on the social and technological origins of significant innovations in 20th-century science." 3684 Chevalley, Catherine. Marie Curie: A life. 509 pp., illus., notes, index. New York: Si- mon &amp; Schuster, 1995. 3804 Rae, Ian D. ICI Fellowships and their effect on Australian chemistry. Hist. Rec. Aust. Sci., 1994, 10: 25-34. "From 1944 to 1975, Imperial Chemical Industries in Britain operated a scheme of doctoral (later postdoctoral) fellowships in British universities which made a substantial contribution to research training and output. Fellowships were awarded in fields of interest to the company-notably in chemistry-and Fellows were under no obligation to work for the company. Australians made up the largest group of overseas recipients of fellowships, and almost all of them returned to posts in Australian universities, so the gains to their country more than offset the small 'brain drain' to Britain that was always inherent in such a scheme." From the abstract. 3805 Reed, Germaine M. Crusading for chemistry: The professional career of Charles Holmes Herty. xiii + 474 pp., illus., notes, bibl., index. "My focus will be on an AEC laboratory, the Oak Ridge National Laboratory in Tennessee. Stanley Auerbach, the first ecologist employed by the laboratory, began his work at Oak Ridge in 1954 by studying radioactive contami- nation near waste-disposal sites. During the next fifteen years, Oak Ridge ecologists expanded outwards from this small beginning, tracing the movement of radionuclides within a variety of habitats. In doing so, Auerbach and his colleagues contributed to a range of AEC and Oak Ridge objectives, and the support for their research grew steadily. By the end of the 1960s Oak Ridge was home to one of the largest ecosystem research programs in the United States." 3884 Bourg, Dominique. Hans Jonas et l'6cologie. "In the present paper I wish to discuss the constrain- ing effect of the relation between the manifest and the scientific image, i.e., between the images of the world constructed on the personal experiences of individuals encountering themselves in society, and the striving for images based on impersonal reasoning, which may involve imperceptible conceptual entities. I shall follow primarily two examples from the early history of genetics. The one is the story of the objects of Darwinian natural selection, 211</page><page sequence="212">39e. Twentieth Century: Biological Sciences which is best known through the clash between biometri- cians and Mendelians in the first decade of the century, and its conceptual (though not actual) resolution through the introduction of the terms phenotype and genotype by Wilhelm Johannsen in 1909. Fr. ttrang., 1995, 185: 43-53. From the end of the 19th century to the present. 3948 Mitchell, Sandra D. The superorgan- ism metaphor: Then and now. Pp. 231-247 in Sabine Maasen (et al., eds.) Biology as soci- ety, society as biology: Metaphors. Dordrecht: Kluwer Academic, 1995. "My paper is concerned with . . . the use of superor- ganism metaphor in biological theory. In particular I am interested in the recent arguments for the 'revival' of the superorganism metaphor for the study of social insects. Briefly, superorganism metaphors and theories take the individual organism as a model of functional integration or cooperation of parts and extend that model to describe and explore social groups of individuals. Just as individual cells in the body cooperate in the development, main- tenance, and reproduction of the organism, so too (it is suggested by the metaphor) do individuals cooperate in the development, maintence, and reproduction of a colony or a society." 3949 Mitman, Gregg. Defining the organism in the welfare state: The politics of individual- ity in American culture, 1890-1950. Pp. 249- 278 in Sabine Maasen (et al., eds.) Biology as society, society as biology: Metaphors. Dor- drecht: Kluwer Academic, 1995. "Throughout the late 19th and early decades of the 20th century, individuality could mean everything from the unity and order in behavior of protoplasm, to hereditary constitution, to something in between. By the late 1940s and early 1950s, consonant with the entrenchment of the modem synthesis and molecular biology, a definition of the individual had narrowed to mean a 'unique, genetically homogeneous, entity.' Intermingled with early-20th century definitions of individuality are a set of keywords such as community, cooperation, freedom, and the common good that were utilized by biologists, but whose etymological roots were derived from political discourse. Exploring the precise etymology by which current definitions of the individual came to fruition and how a web of political, social, and scientific interrelations have bolstered and supported its meaning are the tasks of this essay." 3950 Mooney, Susan M. Milford, Penn.: Grey Towers Press, 1994. 3969 Rheinberger, Hans-Jorg. From micro- somes to ribosomes: "Strategies" of "represen- tation". J. Hist. Biol., 1995, 28: 49-89. "I intend to exemplify these counterintuitive issues on 'strategy' and 'representation' in science by going into considerable detail about a research process that origi- nated at the Rockefeller Institute for Medical Research. It started, in 1911, with Peyton Rous's tentative identifi- cation of a cancer-inducing agent as an ultramicroscopic organism. Through a series of unprecedented events made possible by the conjunction of different techniques of representation, including ultracentrifugation and electron microscopy, this agent was replaced by what for a long time was considered to be, and was structurally described as, a microsome. Through another shift, the microsomal pellet differentiated into a membrane part and a protein- synthesizing organelle, which came to be referred to as the ribosome by the late 1950s." 3970 Robin, Libby. Soc., 1994, 39: 179-197. 3983 Steam, William T. John Williams (1915- 1991) and Adam Stainton (1921-1991), botani- cal explorers of Nepal. Taxon, 1993, 42: 901- 905. 3984 Sullivan, Dale L. Migrating across disci- plinary boundaries: The case of the periodicity paper of David Raup and John Sepkoski. Soc. Epistem., 1995, 9: 151-164. "In this paper I analyse a successful example of interdis- ciplinary rhetoric, an article that was part of an ongoing scientific project attempting to explain the causes of mass extinctions." 3985 Swetlitz, Marc. Julian Huxley and the end of evolution. J. Hist. Biol., 1995, 28: 181-217. "This article does not offer a comprehensive reinterpreta- tion of Huxley's views on progress in evolution. Rather, it focuses on one critical item, hitherto neglected by histo- rians: the claim that large-scale evolution (evolution above the species level) had ended, and thus that only human beings now possessed the capacity for further evolutionary progress. I will argue that Huxley's acceptance of and commitment to this conviction must be understood as the result of the interaction of social values, philosophical beliefs, and contemporary scientific knowledge about the nature and scope of specialization and stabilization in the evolution of life." 3986 Teuber, Marianne L. The founding of the Primate Station, Tenerife, Canary Islands. Amer. J. Psychol., 1994, 107: 551-581. "The Primate Station on Tenerife in the Canary Islands is known for Wolfgang Kohler's experiments (1914-20) on the intelligent behavior of anthropoid apes. The Station was founded in 1912 by Max Rothmann, neurophysiol- ogist at the University of Berlin, and sponsored by the Royal Prussian Academy of Sciences. The present article describes the circumstances and sudden appointment of Eugen Teuber as director." From the abstract. 3987 Theunissen, Bert. Het nut van au- tonomie: Een andere kijk op M.W. Beijerincks microbiologie. (The usefulness of autonomy: A different view of M.W. Beijerinck's micro- biology). Gewina, 1994, 17: 191-205. 3988 Theunissen, Bert. Knowledge is power: Hugo de Vries on science, heredity and social progress. Brit. J. Hist. Sci., 1994, 27: 291- 311. "Here, my aim is not to go further into de Vries' role in the history of Mendelism or the history of the evolu- tionary synthesis, but to reconstruct the cultural and social context within which de Vries' views of heredity and evo- lution took shape. For as I shall try to show, it is only against this background that we can fully appreciate how and why he developed his particular views, while such an approach may also help us to gain a better understanding of the tremendous popularity of the mutation theory in the first decades of the twentieth century." 3989 Thorne, B. Michael. Robert Thomp- son: Karl Lashley's heir? J. Hist. Behav. Sci., 1995, 31: 129-136. "Robert Thompson spent a year as a research assistant at the Yerkes Laboratory of Primate Biology in Orange Park, Florida, where Karl Lashley was the director. After Lashley's death, Thompson began a search for the 'lo- cus of the engram,' which Lashley had been unable to find, eventually providing evidence supporting Wilder Pen- field's conception of a centrencephalic system. Although Thompson's search was ultimately more successful than Lashley's, his name and accomplishments are little known outside a small circle of neuroscientists." 3990 Timofeev-Resovskii, Nikolai V. Vospom- inaniia. [Sostavitel' N.I. Dubrovina]. 381 pp., illus., bibl. Moskva: Progress, 1995. 3991 Turney, Jon. Life in the laboratory: Pub- lic responses to experimental biology. Public Underst. Sci., 1995, 4: 153-176. "Present-day public attitudes to biological manipulation are ambivalent, many surveys show. This paper explores evidence of earlier attitudes to experimental biology, before survey data exists, by examining published responses in the press to the idea that biologists would 'create life'. This remarkable claim achieved wide currency in the early years of this century, particularly linked to the work of two prototypical 'visible scientists': Jacques Loeb and Alexis Carrel." "During the 1945-50 period, Japanese theoretical economists mathematized economics with the coopera- tion of Japanese mathematicians. Mathematicians played the leading part in assimilating European scientific ideas and providing an internationally oriented attitude in Japan from the mid nineteenth century on. Personalities in the crowd: The idea of the "masses" in Amer- ican popular culture. Prospects, 1994, 19: 225-287. "George Creel, Edward L. Bemays, and John B. Watson are most often viewed historically as nefarious manipu- lators of the public mind, and they hardly constituted a school of popular mass culture theory. Rather, they illus- trate historically a continuum of increasingly radical uses of psychological theory in everyday parlance. For most Americans, these three provided the point of entry of psy- chological and social theory into popular thought. More than any of the memorable intellectuals of the 1920s, they introduced common readers to new concepts of irrational behavior, the 'unconscious', and persuasion, ideas that impinged upon not only democratic sensibilities, but also traditional understandings of social relations and the very nature of the modem self." 4132 Southern, David W. The origins and development of the dif- fusion of innovations paradigm as an example of scientific growth. Sci. Commun., 1994, 16: 242-273. "This article traces the emergence of the basic paradigm for early diffusion research created by two rural sociolo- gists at Iowa State University, Bryce Ryan and Neal C. Gross. The diffusion paradigm spread to an invisible col- lege of midwestern rural sociological researchers in the 1950s and 1960s, and then to a larger, interdisciplinary field of diffusion scholars. By the late 1960s, rural sociol- ogists lost interest in diffusion studies, not because it was ineffective scientifically, but because of lack of support for such study as a consequence of farm overproduction and because most of the interesting research questions were thought to be answered." Sci. Context, 1995, 8: 175-196. 'This paper presents two case studies of eugenic legisla- tion. The first is an influential suggestion for a 'Model Eugenical Sterilization Law.' This model law, written by Harry H. Laughlin, a leading American eugenicist, was included in his 1922 book Eugenical Sterilization in the United States, published by the Municipal Court of Chicago. The second case is the verdict of the United States Supreme Court in its 1927 ruling in Buck v. Bell. The issue in this case was the constitutionality of a Vir- ginia statute mandating enforced sterilization (Buck v. Bell 1926)." A commentary, "Eugenics-Medical or social science?" by Peter Weingart follows (pp. 197-207). 229</page><page sequence="230">39g. Iventieth Century: Medicine 4262 Kerl, Jeanne A. New German Crit., 1994, 62: 71-110. "The cyborg, or figure of the 'new man' as a synthesis of organic and technological elements, has played an enduring role in the history of Weimar culture. In part the sign of a fearful response to the terrible destruction brought about by World War I-the first full-scale mechanized conflict in Europe's history-the cyborg was, paradoxically, also a fig- ure upon which a broad range of Weimar modernists could project their utopian hopes and fantasies. In what follows, I wish to direct attention to three moments in this mecha- nized creature's history: 1920, when the cyborg appears in the left-wing sketches and photomontages of Berlin Dada artist Raoul Hausmann; 1926, when the cyborg appears in a starring role in Metropolis, Fritz Lang's ambiguous but ultimately authoritarian science fiction film; and 1933, when the cyborg emerges as one of the controlling im- ages in The Transformed World, a book of photomontage designed by conservative revolutionary Ernst Jtinger to popularize his totalitarian account of technological moder- nity." 4374 Bix, Amy S. On Wiener's work during World War II on the problem of destroying enemy airplanes. "His early efforts at com- putation and antiaircract fire coalesced in a remarkably ambitious calculating device that he called the 'antiair- craft (AA) predictor', designed to characterize an enemy pilot's zigzagging flight, anticipate his future position, and launch an antiaircraft shell to down his plane . . . The AA predictor, along with its associated engineering notions of feedback systems and black boxes, became, for Wiener, 237</page><page sequence="238">39h. Twentieth Century: Technology the model for a cybernetic understanding of the universe itself. 'Tacit knowledge, embodied in people rather than words, equations, or diagrams, plays a vital role in science. The historical record of the development and spread of nuclear weapons and the recollections of their designers suggest that tacit knowledge is also crucial to nuclear weapons development. Therefore, if design ceases, and if there is no new generation of designers to whom that tacit knowledge can be passed, then in an important (though qualified) sense nuclear weapons will have been uninvented."
